question: Two runners A (6 m/s) and B (4 m/s) start together on a 400 m track, same direction. When do they next meet?
raw_extraction: Given as text: same-direction catch-up, track 400 m, speeds 6 and 4.

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed = 6−4 = 2 m/s. Need to gain one full lap (400 m). Time = 400 / 2 = 200 s.
solutions.intuitive: A pulls 2 m ahead each second; needs a full 400 m lead → 200 s.

question: A (8 m/s) and B (7 m/s) run opposite directions on a 300 m track. How many meetings in 2 minutes?
raw_extraction: Opposite direction, track 300 m, speeds 8 and 7.

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed = 8+7 = 15 m/s. Time per meet = 300/15 = 20 s. In 120 s: 120/20 = 6 meetings.
solutions.intuitive: They close 15 m each second; need 300 m gap to meet → every 20 s → 6 times in 120 s.

question: Three runners P,Q,R on 500 m track, speeds 5,4,3 m/s. Same direction. When do all three meet at start again?

solutions.step_by_step: Lap times: P 100 s, Q 125 s, R 500/3 s. Need common multiple: LCM(100,125)=500 s, and 500 is also a multiple of 500/3? 3 laps of R in 500 s → yes. So all at start at 500 s.
solutions.intuitive: Find a time that's whole laps for each. 500 s fits 5 laps for P, 4 for Q, 3 for R.

question: Track 200 m. A lap 25 s, B lap 40 s, same direction. When does A first overtake B?

solutions.step_by_step: Speeds: A=200/25=8 m/s, B=200/40=5 m/s. Relative speed=3 m/s. Need 200 m gain → 200/3 ≈ 66.67 s.
solutions.intuitive: A gains 3 m each second; to be one lap ahead needs 200 m lead → 200/3 s.

question: Track 600 m. Boy1 at 9 m/s starts; Boy2 starts 50 s later at 12 m/s, same direction. When does Boy2 catch Boy1 (time from Boy2 start)?

solutions.step_by_step: Gap after 50 s = 9×50=450 m. On 600 m track, catch-up distance = 600−450=150 m. Relative speed = 3 m/s. Time = 150/3 = 50 s after Boy2 start.
solutions.intuitive: Boy1 is 450 m ahead; Boy2 closes at 3 m/s; needs 150 m on the circle → 50 s.

question: Circular park perimeter 440 m. Two girls start at opposite points, same direction, speeds 6 and 10 m/s. When is first meeting?
raw_extraction: Opposite points → 220 m gap; same direction; speeds 6,10.

solutions.step_by_step: Initial gap = 220 m. Faster speed =10, slower=6, relative=4 m/s. Time = gap/relative = 220/4 = 55 s.
solutions.intuitive: Faster gains 4 m each second on a 220 m head start → 55 s.

question: Two runners lap times 48 s and 72 s. When are they together at start again?

solutions.intuitive: Multiples: 48,96,144 vs 72,144 → first coincide at 144.

question: Track 1 km. A clockwise 4 m/s, B anticlockwise 6 m/s. Meetings in 5 minutes?

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed=10 m/s. Time per meet=1000/10=100 s. In 300 s: 300/100=3 meetings.
solutions.intuitive: They close 10 m/s; one lap gap is 1000 m → every 100 s; in 5 min get 3.

question: Lap times: A 30 s, B 36 s, C 45 s. When are B and C together at start for the second time?

solutions.step_by_step: B–C common start time = LCM(36,45)=180 s (first time). Second time = 2×180=360 s.
solutions.intuitive: Their joint cycle is 180 s; the next repeat is another 180 s → 360 s.

question: Track 360 m. A and B run opposite directions, meet after 8 s. A speed 12 m/s; find B speed.

solutions.intuitive: Together they cover the whole 360 m in 8 s; total speed 45; subtract 12 → 33.

question: Lap times: A 20 s, B 25 s, same direction. How many times does A overtake B in 5 minutes?

solutions.step_by_step: Overtake period = 1 / (1/20 − 1/25) = 100 s. In 300 s → 300/100 = 3 overtakes.
solutions.intuitive: A gains 1/20−1/25=1/100 lap per second → one full lap lead every 100 s → 3 times in 300 s.
solutions.shortcut: Use T = LCM(lap times) / (difference/??) ⇒ here 100 s interval.

question: Track 500 m, opposite directions, speeds 5 and 7 m/s. When is the 6th meeting?

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed=12 m/s. Time per meet = 500/12 ≈ 41.67 s. Sixth meeting at 6×(500/12)=250 s.
solutions.intuitive: They meet every 41.67 s; six meetings take 250 s.

question: Lap 300 m. A lap 40 s, B lap 30 s, opposite directions. Meetings in 4 minutes?

solutions.step_by_step: Speeds: A=7.5 m/s, B=10 m/s. Relative=17.5 m/s. Time per meet=300/17.5=120/7 ≈17.14 s. In 240 s: 240 / (120/7)=14 meetings.
solutions.intuitive: They meet roughly every 17 s; over 240 s that's 14 times.

question: Track 800 m. A at 5 m/s starts; B starts 20 s later at 7 m/s, same direction. When does B first overtake A (from A’s start)?

solutions.direct: 70 seconds from A’s start (50 s after B’s start)
solutions.step_by_step: Gap after 20 s = 5×20=100 m. Relative speed=2 m/s. Time to close =100/2=50 s after B starts. Total from A start = 20+50=70 s.
solutions.intuitive: A gets 100 m head start; B gains 2 m/s; needs 50 s; add the 20 s delay.

question: Opposite directions: A 3 m/s, B 5 m/s. They meet every 20 s. Find track length.

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed=3+5=8 m/s. Distance per meet=8×20=160 m.
solutions.intuitive: They cover the whole circumference together in 20 s at 8 m/s → 160 m.

question: Lap times: A 54 s, B 36 s, same direction. How long until B is one lap ahead of A?

solutions.step_by_step: Relative lap rate = 1/36 − 1/54 = (3−2)/108 = 1/108 lap/s. Time for 1-lap lead = 108 s.
solutions.intuitive: B gains 1/108 of a lap each second; needs 108 s for a full lap gap.

question: Lap times: A 50 s, B 40 s, same direction. When will B be 3 laps ahead of A?

solutions.step_by_step: Relative lap rate = 1/40 − 1/50 = (5−4)/200 = 1/200 lap/s. Time for 3 laps lead = 3×200 = 600 s.
solutions.intuitive: B gains 1/200 lap per second; needs 3 laps ⇒ 600 s.

question: Opposite directions; meet every 15 s. A speed 6 m/s. Find B’s speed and track length (underdetermined).

solutions.direct: Family of solutions: L = 15(6+vB). Need one more condition to fix numbers.
solutions.step_by_step: Meeting condition gives (6+vB) × 15 = L. Infinite pairs (vB,L) satisfy this. Example: if vB=4 m/s, then L=150 m; if vB=6 m/s, L=180 m, etc.
solutions.intuitive: Total speed times meeting interval equals track length; many combinations fit until another constraint is given.
solutions.shortcut: Use L = 15(6+vB); choose vB to determine L.

question: Lap times 18 s, 24 s, 30 s for A,B,C. When are all three at the same position (anywhere on track)?

solutions.step_by_step: LCM(18,24,30)=360 s → all align every 360 s (same position, including start).
solutions.intuitive: Their cycles sync every 360 s.

question: Runner on 400 m track with constant acceleration: first lap 60 s, second lap 50 s. Find acceleration.

solutions.step_by_step: Let v0 be initial speed, a constant acceleration. Distance after 60 s: 400 = 60 v0 + 0.5 a·60². Distance after 110 s total: 800 = 110 v0 + 0.5 a·110². Subtracting gives 400 = 50 v0 + 4250 a. Solve system: v0 = 245 a; plug into first: 400 = 16500 a ⇒ a ≈ 0.02424 m/s²; v0 ≈ 5.94 m/s.
solutions.intuitive: Speeds rise enough to cut lap time from 60 s to 50 s; solving kinematics gives a small acceleration ~0.024 m/s².
solutions.shortcut: Use s=v0 t + 0.5 a t² for t=60 and t=110, solve two equations for a.

question: Two runners A (5 m/s) and B (2 m/s) start together on a 120 m circular track. After how much time do they meet again at the starting point?
raw_extraction: Based on the provided frame... speeds A=5 m/s, B=2 m/s, track=120 m; no steps shown.

solutions.step_by_step: Time per lap: T_A=120/5=24 s, T_B=120/2=60 s. They meet at start after LCM(24,60)=120 s.
solutions.intuitive: One finishes every 24s, the other every 60s; the first common multiple is 120s.
solutions.shortcut: Use LCM of lap times: LCM(120/5,120/2)=120 s.

question: Two runners A (5 m/s) and B (2 m/s) start together on a 120 m circular track. When do they next meet at the starting point?
raw_extraction: Shows track 120 m, speeds 5 m/s and 2 m/s, lists lap times 24s and 60s.

solutions.step_by_step: Lap times: 120/5=24 s, 120/2=60 s. Meeting at start ⇒ LCM(24,60)=120 s.
solutions.intuitive: Look at multiples: A hits start every 24s, B every 60s; first common hit is 120s.
solutions.shortcut: LCM of lap times for same-start meeting = 120 s.

question: Two runners on a 120 m track take 24 s and 60 s per lap. After how much time do they first meet at the starting point?
raw_extraction: Text: TA and TB meet at start = LCM(TA,TB); LCM(24,60)=120.

solutions.step_by_step: Given lap times 24 s and 60 s, first common return to start = LCM(24,60)=120 s.
solutions.intuitive: Think of bus schedules: one every 24s, one every 60s; they coincide at 120s.
solutions.shortcut: LCM of given lap times → 120 s.

question: Two runners on a 120 m circular track take 24 s and 60 s per lap. Find the first three times they are together at the start.

solutions.direct: They meet at start at 120 s, 240 s, 360 s.
solutions.step_by_step: Lap times 24 s and 60 s. Common multiples: 120, 240, 360... so first three meetings are at 120 s, 240 s, 360 s.
solutions.intuitive: Every 24s one is at start; every 60s the other. They coincide every 120s; repeat add 120s.

question: Two runners on a 120 m track take 24 s and 60 s per lap. What is the first time they meet at the start, and how often after that?
raw_extraction: Shows LCM(24,60)=120 noted as M1; M2=240, M3=360.

solutions.direct: First meeting at 120 s; then every 120 s (240 s, 360 s, ...).
solutions.step_by_step: Lap times: 24 s, 60 s. LCM=120 s ⇒ first meeting at 120 s. Subsequent meetings every additional 120 s: 240 s, 360 s...
solutions.intuitive: Their rhythms sync every 120 s; just keep adding 120 to get later meetings.
solutions.shortcut: Use LCM=120, then arithmetic progression with step 120.

question: Two runners on a 120 m circular track take 24 s and 60 s per lap. How long until they next coincide at the start?

solutions.step_by_step: Same-start meeting uses LCM of lap times. LCM(24,60)=120 s.
solutions.intuitive: They align like overlapping clocks; the first sync tick is at 120 s.

question: Two runners A (5 m/s) and B (2 m/s) start together on a 210 m circular track. After how much time do they first meet anywhere on the track?
raw_extraction: Track 210 m, speeds 5 and 2 m/s; relative speed idea noted but no final answer.

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed (same direction) = 5−2=3 m/s. Initial gap = 0; meeting time = track length / relative speed = 210/3 = 70 s.
solutions.intuitive: A gains 3 m each second; needs to gain one full lap (210 m) to catch B ⇒ 210/3=70 s.

question: Two runners A (5 m/s) and B (2 m/s) start together on a 210 m circular track. When do they first meet again anywhere on the track?
raw_extraction: Diagram with 210 m, speeds 5 and 2; formula hint.

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed (same direction) = 3 m/s. Need one-lap gain (210 m) ⇒ time = 210/3 = 70 s.
solutions.intuitive: Picture A pulling 3 m ahead each second; needs 210 m gap ⇒ 70 s.

question: Two runners A (5 m/s) and B (2 m/s) start together on a 210 m track. Find the first meeting time on the track (not necessarily at start).
raw_extraction: Shows formula T=210/(5−2)=70 s, labeled meeting point M.

solutions.step_by_step: Relative speed = 3 m/s. Time to close 210 m gap = 210/3 = 70 s.
solutions.intuitive: A gains 3 m/s; needs one lap lead of 210 m ⇒ 70 s.

question: Two runners A (5 m/s) and B (2 m/s) start together on a 210 m track. How long until A catches B?
raw_extraction: Text shows T=210/(5−2)=70 s; notes M after 70 s.

solutions.step_by_step: Same-direction catch-up: relative speed 3 m/s; distance to gain = 210 m; time = 210/3 = 70 s.
solutions.intuitive: Think of A pulling away 3 m each second; needs one full lap lead to meet B → 70 s.
